messageBody:
Hi,

Thanks for the information.Both the tip works.

I went by 2 ,since i wont need to modify my Orignal
class.

Yoonus
--- Johannes Link <john.link@...> wrote:
> I guess you made the dialog modal. There's a flag
> for that in the JDialog
> constructor.
>
> There are two approaches I have used in that
> situation:
> 1. Provide a constructor which opens the dialog in
> non-modal mode just for
> testing purposes.
>
> 2. Open the dialog in another thread than the
> testing thread:
> private void openDialogInOtherThread() {
> Runnable runnable = new Runnable() {
> public void run() {
> dialog.show(); // =
> dialog.setVisible(true)
> }
> };
> new Thread(runnable).start();
> waitForDialogOpen();
> }
> private void waitForDialogOpen() {
> while (!dialog.isShowing()) {
> try {
> Thread.sleep(10);
> } catch (InterruptedException e) {
> }
> }
> }
>
>
> Now you can perform your tests on dialog as you
> wish. Don't forget to call
> dialog.dispose() in tearDown.
>
> Hope that helps,
> Johannes
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "mailych" mailych@...
>

> >
> > 1 MyClass myclass = new MyClass(title);
> >
> > 2 AbstractButtonTester btnTester = new
> AbstractButtonTester();

> >

> >

KeyboardFocusManager.getCurrentKeyboardFocusManager();

> MyClass.class,

> focusManager.getCurrentFocusCycleRoot().getClass());
> >
> >

> > prints "Before visible" . Only once i close my
> dialog box, it

> > But if MyClass extends JFrame,the code continues

> >
> > Is this a bug??Can anybody suggest a work
> around(except making

> >
